results.title: The Moonbeam princess
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Japanese Fairy Tale”.
A charming Japanese fairy tale about a little princess who came to earth on a moonbeam. Three princes who seek her hand in marriage go in search of three rare and precious gifts to give her. Animated puppet figures in beautiful authentic costumes and background settings, give a delightful artistic flavour to this original story.

results.title: 16mm projector
results.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).
results.brief_description:
Introduced in the 1920’s as a more affordable film format to the industry standard 35mm, 16mm film was popularised by home movie enthusiasts and widely used for educational purposes. Projectors like this Ditmar 16mm became a common piece of audio visual equipment in classrooms and libraries across the world. The popularity of 16mm projectors decreased in the 1980’s as home video technologies were seen as a more cost effective and compact solution to film.

This particular projector belonged to amateur filmmaker Kenneth Rankine, whose collection of home movies and film equipment were generously donated to ACMI by his granddaughter.

results.title: A History of British art
results.brief_description: Andrew Graham-Dixon examines British art- its lost medieval legacy, and why it developed differently to the European mainstream.

results.title: 16MM Sound Projector, RST Series
results.brief_description:
Introduced in the 1920’s as a more affordable film format to the industry standard 35mm, 16mm film was popularised by home movie enthusiasts and widely used for educational purposes. Projectors like this Hanimex Eiki 16MM increasingly became a common piece of audio visual equipment within schools and libraries across the world. This particular projector features textured metal casing and a handle for portability convenience.

The popularity of 16mm projectors began to decrease in the 1980’s as home video technologies were seen as a more cost effective and compact solution to film.

results.title: All change
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “A History of British art”.
Having invented modern painting, the British turned their backs on it. The vigour of 19th century engineering is contrasted with the moralising character of its arts, and its need to smother the radical energies of the nation. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Modern art
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode four of ‘A History of British art’ shows that what is commonly thought of as modern painting began with Constable and Turner in England, where for the first time the artist insisted on his own version as the guiding principle. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Judy Maddigan
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Judy Maddigan was the first woman Deputy Speaker and was the first woman to be appointed the Speaker of The Legislative Assembly in Victoria in 2003. Maddigan has a strong commitment to community and was elected as a Member of Parliament to represent the Electoral District of Essendon in the Legislative Assembly in 1996. During her time as speaker Maddigan implemented many changes in the 150 year old parliament to improve the lives of workers and also public accessibility. She is a librarian at heart and is currently the Member for Essendon.

results.title: My wife, my horse and myself
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A History of British art”.
The traditional 18th century style, portraits of dogs, horses and family was the province of British artists; their aristocratic clients bought their ‘real art’ in Italy. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: North and south
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode two of ‘A History of British art’ looks at the brilliant, mad excessiveness of the Elizabethan visual imagination, in architecture, painting, gardening and language. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Dreams and hammers
results.creator_credit: Paul Tickell, Tanya Seghatchian and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode one of ‘A History of British art’ looks at two extraordinary, forgotten legacies at the heart of the British art tradition: the lost tradition of Catholic medieval art, and the tradition of post-Reformation iconoclasm- an entire culture that was devoted to destroying art. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.
